abstract.p: The writer Nakagami Kenji (1946-1992) rose to fame in the mid-1970s for his vivid stories about a clan scarred by violence and poverty on the underside of the Japanese economic miracle. Drawing upon the lives, experiences, and languages of the burakumin, the outcaste communities long discriminated against in Japanese society as a defiled underclass, Nakagami’s works of fiction and nonfiction record with vitality and violence the realities—actual and imagined—of buraku culture. In this critical study of Nakagami’s life and oeuvre, Eve Zimmerman delves into the writer’s literary world, exploring the genres, forms, and themes with which Nakagami worked and experimented. These chapters trace the biographical thread running through his works while foregrounding such diverse facets of his writing as his interest in the modern possibilities of traditional myths and forms of storytelling, his deployment of shocking tropes and images, and his crafting of a unique poetic language. By bringing to the fore the literary urgency and social engagement that informed all aspects of Nakagami’s creative and intellectual production, from his works of prose and poetry to his criticism, this book argues eloquently and effectively for us to appreciate Nakagami as a distinctive and relevant voice in modern Japanese literature.

Nakagami Kenji (1946–1992) rose to fame in the mid-1970s for his vivid stories about a clan scarred by violence and poverty on the underside of the Japanese economic miracle. Wrung from his own experience growing up in a provincial city in southeastern Wakayama, Nakagami’s writing burst apart stereotypes of a serene, precious, and exotic Japan. Possessing a highly sensitive ear, he wrote a rhythmic, kinetic prose that in the early years of his writing career scans in short poetic breaths and in his later work winds into great streams of words. We talked for over an hour before conversation was cut short by the arrival of the gospel choir. abstract.p: In August 1966, Nakagami Kenji published a handful of poems inMichi, a local Shingū literary magazine. Soon after publication, he attended a gathering in Shingū to celebrate the tenth issue of the magazine in hopes of hearing comments on his poetry. Unfortunately, the audience asked only a few questions about specific words in the poems, waiting patiently for the author to explain his own work. Asamori Mizuho, the editor of the magazine, reported that people had complained about the difficulty of the poems even as some declared that they must be masterpieces.¹

abstract.p: On July 29, 1978, Nakagami Kenji addressed a local audience at the Rinpōkan, theburakucommunity center in the Kasuga district of Shingū. His subject that day was a folksong about brother-sister love, replete with a bold confession, mistaken identities, and tragic death. During the 1970s the song was still performed (and danced) every year in August at theobonfestival for the dead in Shingū. A thread emerges in the work of a younger brother who struggles to resist a family or a community that threatens to engulf him. In 1978, Nakagami Kenji, aged 35, traveled from Tokyo to Shingū, where he made a short film of the Shingū alleyway, which was in its final stages of “urban renewal.” Panning down narrow alleyways with a 16-millimeter camera, Nakagami’s lens lingered on the small houses, the close-fitting roofs, the potted plants, and the sweets displayed in the local shop. With images of a neighborhood that was soon to be destroyed by the wrecker’s ball, Nakagami created a visual record of the place that had nourished his fiction.
